column2: A 42-year-old female patient reports pain with inflammatory features and swelling in both wrists, 2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally and left ankle of 4 months of evolution accompanied by morning stiffness of more than one hour duration
column3: Laboratory tests showed Hb: 10 g/dL with ESR of 45 mm in the first hour, CRP 16 mg/L, rheumatoid factor 160 IU/ML

column2: A 42-year-old female patient reports pain with inflammatory features and swelling in both wrists, 2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally and left ankle of 4 months of evolution accompanied by morning stiffness of more than one hour duration
column3: After 6 months of treatment with indomethacin and methotrexate, the patient persists with pain and swelling of both carpals, morning stiffness lasting 30 minutes and a CBC showing an ESR 30 mm in the first hour and a CRP 9 mg/dL

column2: A 42-year-old female patient reports pain with inflammatory features and swelling in both wrists, 2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally and left ankle of 4 months of evolution accompanied by morning stiffness of more than one hour duration
column3: Suspend the prescribed treatment due to lack of response and initiate prednisone at high doses for symptom control only

column2: A 42-year-old female patient reports pain with inflammatory features and swelling in both wrists, 2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally and left ankle of 4 months of evolution accompanied by morning stiffness of more than one hour duration

column2: A 42-year-old female patient reports pain with inflammatory features and swelling in both wrists, 2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally and left ankle of 4 months of evolution accompanied by morning stiffness of more than one hour duration

column2: A 42-year-old female patient reports pain with inflammatory features and swelling in both wrists, 2nd and 3rd metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally and left ankle of 4 months of evolution accompanied by morning stiffness of more than one hour duration

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: An emergency operation was performed by cleaning (Friederich) and placement of an endomedullary steel-plated nail

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: At 11 months he presents with atrophic pseudarthrosis of the tibia with suppuration in the wound area

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: Triple antibiotherapy (gram-positive, gram-negative and anaerobic) and cleaning of the surgical wound, removing the distal locks to promote bone consolidation

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: Expectant attitude and antibiotic treatment with quinolones

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: Autologous graft and growth factors (BMP 2 and 7) to stimulate the bone consolidation process, which is slowing

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: Removal of the nail, debridement, placement of external fixator and antibiotherapy adjusted to culture results

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: The first thing is to treat the infection and for this we must remove all the osteosynthesis material, debride and give antibiotherapy

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: We are dealing with an infection associated with an implant (intramedullary nail) and pseudoarthrosis of the tibia fracture (absence of union after 11 months)

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: The infection is understood by the clinical manifestations (suppuration, nonunion) and the history of diabetes and open fracture

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: Suppressive antibiotic treatment: indicated in patients with Ciemy type C, it consists of prolonged oral antibiotic therapy for at least 6 months to "cool" the exacerbation of the clinical picture

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: Curative treatment: includes a first surgery with aggressive tumor-like debridement of all affected tissues, profuse irrigation, stabilization with external fixator if stability is compromised, and eventual filling of the cavities with antibiotic-releasing substances

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: After prolonged periods of antibiotic therapy selected according to the antibiograms of the cultures, and once it is certain that the infection has been cured, special techniques for the reconstruction of the bone defect and to achieve adequate coverage of soft tissues should be considered

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: Management overlaps with the management of chronic osteomyelitis

column2: A 70-year-old woman, diabetic and hypertensive, who suffers a fall at home, presenting a 9 cm wound communicating with a fracture site of the right tibia
column3: Isolated antibiotherapy (option 2) is indicated only in patients with severe comorbidity in whom surgical treatment would be more aggressive than continuing the disease

column3: Post-traumatic hypovolemia

column2: Post-traumatic hypovolemia (in this case, as there are multiple rib fractures, it could be due to hemothorax) would occur earlier and would be associated in the first place with hemodynamic instability
column3: Pulmonary contusion is the most serious lesion and the one with the worst prognosis in thoracic trauma

column2: Post-traumatic hypovolemia (in this case, as there are multiple rib fractures, it could be due to hemothorax) would occur earlier and would be associated in the first place with hemodynamic instability
column3: It is also the injury that causes hypoxemia the earliest

column2: Post-traumatic hypovolemia (in this case, as there are multiple rib fractures, it could be due to hemothorax) would occur earlier and would be associated in the first place with hemodynamic instability
column3: Contrary to what we may think, an unstable thorax due to multiple rib fractures (costal volet) would cause progressive hypoventilation with atelectasis of the pulmonary parenchyma, which would progress on the one hand to hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis, and on the other, to later hypoxemia due to infection associated with atelectasis

column2: Post-traumatic hypovolemia (in this case, as there are multiple rib fractures, it could be due to hemothorax) would occur earlier and would be associated in the first place with hemodynamic instability
column3: Respiratory infection due to aspiration would also occur later, and does not appear in all cases of severe chest trauma, only if there has been a decrease in the level of consciousness (associated TBI, uncontrolled intubation with bronchoaspiration...)

column3: An 86-year-old woman in whom nonvalvular atrial fibrillation has been detected
She has a CHADS2 score of 3 points
In the literature, similar patients on warfarin therapy have a stroke risk of 2.2% versus 5.2% in patients without warfarin
the number needed to treat (NNT) to prevent embolic stroke with anticoagulation therapy
The NNT (number needed to treat), means how many patients we would need to treat with an intervention to obtain a benefit
in this question how many patients do we need to treat with warfarin to prevent a stroke
To calculate this we use the following formula: NNT= 1/RRA (RRA: absolute risk reduction)
RRA= Io - Ie (Io: incidence in those not exposed to warfarin; Ie: incidence in those exposed to warfarin)

column3: Therefore, if that is our first diagnostic suspicion, the HABITUAL test (as the statement says) for diagnosis should be a conventional karyotype (formula: 45, X0)

column2: 15-year-old female presenting with delayed menarche and short stature
column3: A Turner can also be diagnosed with a FISH (there would only be one signal for the X instead of the two that females usually have) or with an array

column2: 15-year-old female presenting with delayed menarche and short stature
column3: However, both array and NGS are usually reserved for patients with non-obvious clinical pictures, intellectual disability, or suspicion of a genetic syndrome that requires these specific tests (for example, an array to diagnose a 22q11 deletion syndrome or an NGS panel to diagnose a Noonan syndrome)
